data.title: Forecasting Bond Fund Returns In A Post-2021 Regime Isn't Getting Any Easier
data.description:
By James Picerno

Developing reliable return expectations for bonds is straightforward, at least compared with the far greater uncertainty associated with stocks. But the relative reliability for projecting performance with fixed-income securities is closely linked to buying and holding a bond through its maturity date. Results over shorter periods can and often do vary substantially. Investing in bond funds introduces more return variability vs. the implied outlook with a relevant buy-and-hold position in an individual Treasury security or corporate bond.

A high degree of clarity for expected return with bonds is a function of using the current yield at the time of purchase as a forecast. For example, a 5-year Treasury Note is currently trading around 3.7%. Assuming you purchase the security directly at that current yield and hold it through maturity, the performance will roughly match the yield at the time of purchase. (Technically, yield-to-maturity, which factors in additional variables, is a more accurate measure for projecting return, but for simplicity in this illustration, let’s assume current yield is equivalent. Note, too, that we’re ignoring such issues as how you invest a bond’s payouts through time and other variables, such as callable bonds and defaults that affect returns for corporates.)

Investing in bonds by way of a fund adds another layer of complication that can, and usually does, affect performance - sometimes in ways that aren’t intuitive. As an example, consider a buy-and-hold investment in Vanguard Total Bond Market Index Fund (VBMFX), a popular mutual fund that holds investment-grade securities.

Morningstar reports that a bit more than half of VBMFX’s portfolio is held in US government bonds, with corporates (25%) and securitized bonds making up most of the rest (22%). The fund’s yield to maturity is 4.38%.

Assume the 5-year Treasury yield is a proxy for the fund, which implies that when you bought VBMFX, the current 5-year rate is a reasonable first approximation of what you can expect to earn over the next 5 years. The broader portfolio holdings in VBMFX will create differences vs. a 5-year Note, but current yield for the government security should be a decent back-of-the-envelope forecast.

Sometimes that’s a reasonable assumption, but it can also be wide of the mark. Much depends on current macro conditions and the outlook when you buy VBMFX.

For context, the chart below compares the 5-year annualized total return for VBMFX five years hence relative to the 5-year yield. If the 5-year yield was a perfect forecast for VBMFX’s return five years down the road, the two lines would match exactly. Clearly, that’s not the case. Although there are periods when the 5-year yield (red line in chart) is a reasonably accurate estimate of the future 5-year return for VBMFX (black line), there can be substantial divergences for prolonged periods.

For most of VBMFX’s history, the fund has outperformed or matched the 5-year yield. But since the Federal Reserve’s latest round of rate hikes starting in 2022, VBMFX’s five-year return has trailed the 5-year yield (from five years earlier) by a relatively wide margin for an extended period.

There are several possible reasons for the mismatch in recent years, including the rapid pace of 2022-2023 rate hikes, the lingering effects of the pandemic on the economy, and the sharp spike in inflation in 2022-2023.

Another relevant factor: the four-decade trend of generally declining interest rates that ended in 2021. Forty years of falling yields bred a high degree of comfort in assuming that risk was minimal for the bond market’s outlook. When that regime ended, the shift introduced more uncertainty and volatility into the market to a degree unseen in decades.

Even before 2021, it was unsurprising that VBMFX’s rolling 5-year return deviated from the implied forecast via a 5-year yield. The fund, although it tracks an index, holds a range of bonds and therefore takes more risk vs. a Treasury note. The higher risk mostly paid off, until the 2022 rate hikes.

The larger point is that developing return and risk expectations for bond funds has become considerably more nuanced. By contrast, forecasting VBMFX and other bond strategies was more or less pro forma in the pre-2021 era, with relatively low stakes given the general slide in yields.

That era ended in 2022, and it’s debatable when or if it will return. Between tariffs, gridlock in government, elevated fiscal risk for the US government, and the potential for AI-fueled economic disruption, a repeat performance of the secular slide in interest rates during 1981-2021 looks unlikely, at least at the moment.

In turn, the stakes are higher for crunching the numbers and reading the trends for developing expectations for bond funds.

Buying and holding a Treasury note, by comparison, still offers simplicity and relative reliability for projecting future performance.

Original Source: The Milwaukee Company

data.title: Carvana: Buy The Earnings Drop (Upgrade)
data.description:
One of the best turnaround stories has been Carvana (CVNA). The used car retailer, which some like myself thought could go bankrupt just a few years ago, has been one of the best-performing stocks in recent years. On Wednesday, the company announced its third-quarter results, and while the stock dropped afterwards, there were certainly many things to like.

Previous Coverage Of The Name

It's been about two and a half years since I last covered Carvana, at which point I remained a major skeptic. At that time, revenues were falling as the company was pulling back on inventory to stem major cash burn, and the balance sheet was in terrible shape. With a so-so margin picture and not much room to grow in the near term, the once booming stock traded for just around $11 a share. With things improving significantly since, this has been one of the market's biggest rallies, up over 2,700%, compared to a 65% gain for the S&P 500.

A Look At The Q3 Results

For the September ending period, Carvana announced retail units sold of 156,000, or more than 44% growth over the prior year period. With some help from average selling prices, the company reported record quarterly revenue of $5.65 billion. This number was up 55% year over year, and it crushed street estimates by more than $550 million. Total revenues have more than doubled from where they were just two years earlier. Thanks to seven straight quarterly revenue beats and management's hope to get to 3 million annual deliveries within 5 to 10 years, analyst revenue estimates for future years have soared, as seen in the table below.

The biggest key to the ongoing turnaround has been major cost management. As the company has worked to integrate the ADESA sites it acquired over time, along with reducing operating expenses per unit, overall margins have improved tremendously. In Q3 2022, for instance, gross margins were 10.6%, and operating margins were negative 15%. In the just reported quarter, however, those numbers had jumped to 20.3% and a positive 9.8%, respectively. On the operating side, that's more than $1 billion of improvement. Even with gross margins down 175 basis points year over year, management was still able to drive a 55-basis-point increase for its operating margins.

As revenues continue to grow over time, the bottom line could look even better. While the gross margin percentage may not rise every single quarter, gross margin dollars should benefit from the top-line increase. It also appears that as the company continues to sell more vehicles, it may be able to reduce operating expenses as a percentage of revenue another percentage point or two. Finally, interest expenses were still running at a half-billion-dollar pace in Q3 2025, and annual positive cash flow moving forward will help to bring those payments down further from the nearly $700 million run rate peak they were at in early 2024.

Major Balance Sheet Improvement

My biggest concern back in the day was the company's balance sheet. With the company losing money for a time, and also spending wildly to grow, cash burn was extremely high. Just two and a half years ago, net debt was nearly $8 billion, and there was a lot of talk about a potential bankruptcy. Carvana struck a major debt deal with lenders, and since then, the situation has improved tremendously, as seen in the chart below.

At the end of September, the net debt figure was down to just around $3 billion. Total cash was more than $2.1 billion, while total debt stood at just over $5.2 billion. The company has diluted investors a bit over the years to help with its debt pile, but it shouldn't need any substantial equity raises moving forward unless it is for a major acquisition. With the surge in shares in recent years, even a couple of percent of dilution now would wipe out a significant amount of the company's remaining debt.

Free cash flow in the first 9 months of the year was just over half a billion dollars. While that was down from nearly $800 million in the first three quarters of last year, it was mainly due to an extra $522 million spent on inventory. Positive cash flow will allow for more debt repurchases, and as mentioned on the conference call, another nearly $100 million worth of notes were bought back in October.

Valuation Is High, But It Has Certainly Come Down

With Thursday's more than 13.8% drop, Carvana currently has a market cap of about $66.5 billion. Based on current revenue estimates, that means the stock trades for about 2.67 times next year's projected revenue. That is a major premium to names like CarMax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), who both go for about 0.25 times their projected 2026 sales. However, those two names are projected for very limited revenue growth, while Carvana is seeing its top line soar.

With shares of Carvana about $100 off their 52-week high, and revenue estimates jumping as shown above, that valuation has certainly improved. The stock was going for well over 4 times next year's expected sales just a few months ago. As pointed out in the company's shareholder letter, growth currently dwarfs the industry (44% unit growth in Q3 vs. 0% average), and margins are considerably higher (11.3% Adjusted EBITDA vs. 5.0% average).

Wall Street analysts are also very positive on the name currently. As of Thursday morning, 14 of the 22 analysts covering the name had either a "Buy" or "Strong Buy" recommendation on the stock, with just one "Strong Sell," and seven holds. The average price target as of Thursday night was just about $424, implying nearly 39% upside from current levels.

Final Thoughts And Recommendation

While Carvana shares tumbled on Thursday, the company's Q3 report showed just how much of a turnaround has been completed here. No longer is the company losing money and burning through large amounts of cash. Revenue growth is soaring with decent margins, and positive cash flow has helped to significantly improve what was once a hideous balance sheet.

With the company having just 1.5% market share currently, there is plenty of room for future growth, especially given a lack of meaningful presence in some areas of the country, seen below. Just a doubling of market share would put the company over a million retail units sold a year, and management hopes to get well beyond that in the next decade.

While the valuation here certainly is high compared to peers, you aren't going to get this kind of growth elsewhere in the space. With Carvana's worst days behind it, I think this pullback provides an opportunity for those looking to "buy," and thus that will be my new rating here today. I was definitely one of the company's biggest skeptics a few years ago, but the major turnaround here now has me believing that there are still gains to be had for shareholders moving forward.

data.title: Shake Shack: Robust Fundamentals And Attractive Valuation Should Heat Up Momentum
data.description:
In the month that followed my last coverage on Shake Shack Inc. (SHAK), the price has weakened further by 8.2%. While this could suggest that my call was a bit too early considering the cautious stance of the market, its valuation was justified then. And now, SHAK is becoming more attractive with its robust Q3 2025 performance and well-positioned fundamentals. Market challenges are still there, but resilience is present. Technicals are still weak, but bullish divergences are appearing once again.

SHAK Q3 2025: Its Strength Sustained

The macroeconomic environment remains challenging for many restaurants. Discretionary spending is still experiencing softness as inflation affects purchasing power. Yet, those who capitalize on value propositions and prudent and cautious expansion are taking advantage of the situation. Increasing brand popularity also bolsters their demand. Shake Shack, Inc. also enjoys this trend as reflected by its Q3 2025 performance.

Its operating revenue amounted to $367.4M, up by 16% YoY from $316.9M. Its company-operated and franchised stores were stronger during the quarter as Shack sales and licensing revenue rose. As you can see, systemwide sales reached $571.5M, a 15% YoY increase from Q3 2024. At first glance, one might think that this was only due to SHAK’s continued expansion. After all, it opened a total of 13 new company-operated and seven licensed Shacks during the quarter. But if we look closely, SHAK really had a stronger performance. Note that it already has 630 restaurants today versus 552 restaurants on a YoY basis. With that, Shacks generated average sales of $907,143 versus $896,919. This is also higher than in my previous coverage.

Q3 2024 Q2 2025 Q3 2025
Systemwide Sales $495.1M $549.9M $571.5M
Restaurant Count 552 610 630
Average Sales Per Restaurant $896,919 $901,475 $907,143

In addition, SHAK did not become too complacent with its expansion. In fact, it appears more efficient today than in the previous year despite higher cost pressures. Its total operating expenses only increased by 4%, so revenue growth is more than enough to offset it. As a result, its operating margin improved from -5.6% to 5.0% YoY.

It Remains Well Positioned

Inflation is still a challenge for many restaurants. I know that this impacts fast-food restaurants much more than fine-dining and fast-casual restaurants like SHAK. Yet, there may be a point where inflation reaches a point where consumers might rethink their spending habits. Although it capitalizes on value propositions rather than pricing strategies, SHAK may still be affected. Note that inflation has already regained momentum to its 14-month high of 3.0%. Nonetheless, SHAK has natural insulation, making it well-positioned against headwinds and for possible market opportunities.

1. Premium Pricing Gives It Some Flexibility

Because of value propositions and target market, fast-casual restaurants like SHAK set premium prices on burgers, unlike quick-service restaurants, such as McDonald's Corporation (MCD) and Burger King ("BK"). It can set higher prices as it boasts product quality and extra convenience for customers. With that, sales and margins are still increasing. Costs and expenses remain well-managed. If inflation skyrockets and impacts demand, I believe that SHAK can afford to lower prices to still attract and stabilize demand without sacrificing margins. It may even narrow its gap from the QSRs I mentioned, which may highlight product differentiation. As a result, it can take away a portion of their demand.

2. Prudent And Cautious Expansion Protects Its Topline Growth

Despite its increasing popularity in recent years, SHAK prevents itself from overexpanding. It still has less than 1,000 stores globally, although its store openings continue to increase. This prevents unnecessary expenses and cash burns considering macroeconomic volatility.

In addition, most Shacks are located in prime locations like central business districts, national airports, luxury malls, and near large hotels. That way, it is likely that the people in the vicinity can afford to purchase its products. It can also avoid direct competition with cheaper options. This is a very crucial consideration in emerging and third-world economies because of the tendency to value prices more than value propositions. And the way I see it, SHAK is successful in it. A perfect example is in my country, the Philippines. You can only see Shacks in prime locations, especially malls that are frequented by people from middle-income to upper-middle-income households.

On top of these facts, SHAK is increasing its exposure to franchised or licensed shacks. In fact, it now has 271 licensed Shacks versus 242 YoY. In addition, its licensing revenue per restaurant in Q3 2025 averaged at $53,700 versus $49,700 YoY. This proves that increasing licensed restaurants is fruitful for SHAK. It also helps increase its brand popularity with less capital intensity and expenses. So, it can manage its capex, borrowings, and operating costs and expenses better.

3. Shifting Consumer Preferences Move In Favor Of Shake Shack

Another factor is the increased health consciousness of consumers. While these are typically behavioral, I believe that the pandemic stimulated this trend. People going for healthier options open new opportunities. We know that burgers are often considered junk foods. But the narrative may be different for Shake Shack Hamburger. It's a classic hamburger that only has 370 calories and 24 grams of carbohydrates. What makes it more interesting is its whopping 25 grams of protein, an important component for building muscles.

4. Robust Fundamentals Are A Testament To Its Solid Business Model And Strategies

Its capex is over $100M, which is not surprising since it has a higher concentration on company-operated Shacks. Despite this, its operating cash flow remains high enough to cover capex. In fact, it generated an FCF of $152.5M, which means that it converted 15% of its sales into free cash using the FCF/Sales Ratio. This amount is also enough to cover all remaining outflows, such as debt repayments and stock repurchases. With that, SHAK has a very high liquidity as its cash level keeps increasing.

It is also worth noting that it has a relatively low and stable debt level with a long maturity profile. In fact, no amount will mature within a year. Cash alone can cover the whole amount in a single payment even if SHAK doesn’t have to. Indeed, it has a large buffer to sustain its expanding operating capacity. It maintains enough income and cash reserves to expand even without increasing its borrowings.

Valuation

The continued price decrease in SHAK makes it even more attractive today. This justifies my Hold rating at $130. And even if I was a bit early to rate it a buy at $99, the dip opens more buying opportunities. This is proven by my updated valuation. As you can see, the price remains cheap relative to previous years. Using P/S, the price only trades at 2.73x versus the five-year average of 3.45x. If I use this to derive the fair value, the target price or TP will be $115.57. The same applies to cash per share as it only trades at 10.23x versus the average of 12.29x. This gives a TP of $109.72. And even if I add a 10% risk consideration, SHAK will still appear quite underpriced due to the new TPs of $104.02 and $98.76.

While price ratios are historical, they can point to the potential direction of the stock price. Note that the regression model in my previous coverage revealed a high correlation between cash per share and the EPS. It also showed that their direct relationship did not happen by chance. So, valuation makes sense today.

Technicals

SHAK’s technicals still show bearish tendencies as the price decreases with lower highs and lows. It is also below the 50-day and 200-day SMA, so the downtrend still holds. The 50-day SMA is also still trending downwards below the 200-day SMA, so market sentiment is still quite pessimistic. On the other hand, we can note that the price and 50-day SMA downtrends have flattened a bit recently. This can tell us that buyers have started seeing the current price as an ideal entry point.

Meanwhile, MACD and RSI show early bullish divergences. As you can see, the MACD line has increased as the price kept decreasing. This can imply that the stock has become attractive for many buyers. Although it is still within negative territory, it has already crossed above the signal line close to zero, showing that buying volume has increased recently. It is also worth noting that the histogram is moving within positive territory, so buying volume has already outpaced selling volume. RSI may explain this because the stock became oversold, prompting new entries at $91-95. Now, the trend has already normalized, which can lead to consolidation. But since it’s quite close to the oversold region, there is still wide room for buying and may drive some upside.

Conclusion

Shake Shack, Inc. remains a strong and well-positioned company, supported by its prudent and cautious expansion and pricing strategies. Fundamentals are also robust, which ensures the longevity and sustainability of its increasing capacity. These aspects can justify its valuation and may prompt upside. Technicals are still bearish, but recent overselling and early bullish tendencies open new buying opportunities. I’m reiterating my Buy rating on SHAK stock.

data.title: AbbVie: Why Q3 Confirms Its Immunology Dominance
data.description:
Yes, as always, I'll start with a quote, but today it's from "A Farewell to Arms," by my favorite writer, Ernest Hemingway.

The world breaks everyone and afterward many are strong at the broken places. But those that will not break it kills. It kills the very good and the very gentle and the very brave impartially.

Here, everything is quite simple, because I consider it as one of the most accurate quotes that can describe what's happening to AbbVie Inc. (ABBV) right now when its CEO, Rob Michael, despite the success of Rinvoq/Skyrizi, is actively diversifying its portfolio of drugs into the immuno-oncology space, for example, with Elahere and Epkinly, as well as acquiring Capstan [June 30] and Nimble Therapeutics.

Okay, enough with the introductions, and I'd like to continue our "journey" with something a bit more relevant and interesting.

AbbVie's revenue was $15.78 billion for the three months ended September 30, up 9.1% year-on-year thanks to more than solid performance from its immunology [$7.9 billion], excluding Humira, and neuroscience franchises, whose sales I also marked in the plot below.

Also, AbbVie did not fail me and its investors with non-GAAP EPS, as it came in at $1.86, beating Wall Street's consensus forecast by 8 cents and even my "base-case" scenario by 6 cents.

And finally, now, I will show you 4 factors, and a little bit beyond them that will explain why I believe AbbVie will retain its status as one of the best Big Pharma stocks not only for 2025, but at least for 2026.

Big surprises from AbbVie's immunology portfolio

My next obvious step will be to discuss the performance of the "trio" of AbbVie's immunology franchise [Skyrizi, Rinvoq and Humira], and I think you understand why, and if not, it's because their total sales accounted for 50% of its Q3 revenue.

But then again, I will certainly continue to talk about and evaluate how well Elahere [FRα-directed ADC against ovarian cancer] and Botox [for example, used to treat chronic migraine and cervical dystonia] performed as one of the "flagships" in AbbVie's oncology and neuroscience portfolios, respectively.

Well, I will get straight to the point, namely, the recent milestones of Rinvoq.

Of them, I want to take a closer look at the SELECT-SWITCH study [NCT05814627] because it compared the efficacy of Rinvoq with its predecessor, a TNFα antibody called Humira.

So, Rinvoq, being a JAK inhibitor, which I consider the "gold standard" in this drug class, was the first to show the immunology community that it can become a highly effective alternative to TNF inhibitor therapy for people suffering from an inflammatory joint disease called moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis.

Why do I think so? It's pretty simple, as 28.4% of patients in the Rinvoq group achieved remission [measured by DAS28-CRP<2.6], which is almost 2 times more than those taking Humira.

Moreover, I believe Rinvoq scored more than a convincing victory on the primary endpoint [DAS28-CRP≤3.2], where 43.4% of those taking it achieved low rheumatoid arthritis disease activity compared to 22.4% of those in the Humira group [P<0.001].

I'm done with the "science" part and will continue with the discussion of the performance of Humira, Rinvoq, and Skyrizi, as I've found something interesting, intriguing that can't be seen without Allka Research's "microscope." And Humira will be my first "sample."

So, I wasn't surprised to see its sales drop 55.4% and 16% year-over-year and quarter-on-quarter, respectively, to $993 million this quarter. If you want to ask why, obviously because of its 10 biosimilars, among which I highlight Pfizer's (PFE) Abrilada, Amgen's (AMGN) Amjevita, and Alvotech/Teva Pharmaceuticals' (TEVA) (ALVO) Simlandi.

But Rinvoq and Skyrizi are coming to the help of AbbVie, as I've already seen this over the past 11 quarters.

Rinvoq net revenues were $2.2 billion in Q3, up 35.3% year-over-year, and beat my "best-case" scenario by $105 million for two reasons.

I consider its dominant position in the psoriatic arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis therapeutics markets as a key one, and the second factor is the more than successful introduction of Rinvoq into clinical practice for the treatment of GCA in the U.S. [approved on April 29] and Europe [April 8].

Meanwhile, Skyrizi continues to "hit home runs," namely its sales increasing by 46.9% year-on-year to $4.7 billion, in my opinion, due to its outstanding efficacy not only relative to rivals in the IL-23 inhibitor market, but also to Takeda's (TAK) Entyvio [α4β7 integrin inhibitor] and Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ) Stelara [anti-IL-12/IL-23 antibody] in the treatment of ulcerative colitis.

I'm also done with this. And finally, it's time for the thing that I've suspected for months, but after I created the following scatter plot, all the pieces of the puzzle fell into place in my head this early morning.

What do I see here, below? Before I answer it, I'll explain how this graph works, just in case. If you draw an imaginary line down, it will show how sales of Rinvoq+Skyrizi change on a quarterly basis [for example, I'll take Q4/Q3 orange, their sales grew by 12.8%], and if you do the same to the left, it will show the change in sales for Humira.

The colors of the circles indicate the year [blue is 2022], and I also label when one year is changed to another.

So, now I will not distract you and will simply state that Rob Michael and the previous AbbVie CEO, Richard Gonzalez, did an excellent job; namely, Skyrizi and Rinvoq not only offset the decline in demand for Humira, but, most importantly, are rapidly growing "cash cows." I can see this in the cluster I've marked as the purple box.

And yes, another curious thing: in the upper right corner [yellow box], I clearly see that sales of this "trio" are growing in Q2/Q1 in all years. And in the lower left corner [brown oval], a group of three dots has formed, which I believe is due to the fact that AbbVie always, in 2022-2025, offers a discount on Humira and also on Rinvoq/Skyrizi.

Risks

And again, risks. I found basically nothing bad in the Q3 report, except that the sales of Lumigan/Ganfort [eye drops] and Imbruvica [BTK inhibitor against leukemia and cGVHD] are again making me sad.

Takeaway

Besides its immunology franchise, Elahere, and Venclexta, I single out Botox Therapeutic, Ubrelvy, Vraylar, Qulipta, and Vyalev as the "Fantastic Five."

I'm not taking into account Duodopa, precursor of dopamine used against Parkinson's disease, because it's a "dark spot" and a disappointment for both me and AbbVie.

Lastly, I want to say another 9 words: I continue to cover AbbVie with a Strong Buy rating.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Cementos Pacasmayo's 2 Engines Are Thrusting At Least Into H1 2026, And The Price Remains Attractive
data.description:
Cementos Pacasmayo S.A.A. (CPAC) reported 3Q25 results this week.

The company continues to show volume strength thanks to the combination of infrastructure projects (carrying cement and concrete demand) and a better agricultural economy in the North of Peru. Margins have decreased because of bonus expenses related to union negotiations, but they should improve at these volumes next year.

Overall, since I last wrote about Pacasmayo with a Buy rating in late July 2025, the company's share price is up 16%. I believe the name remains attractive given that I believe it can maintain a cash profitability of about $70 million, plus growth of LSD/MSD, compared to a market cap of $600 million.

Good volumes and pricing

After a few years of moderate volumes in self-construction, the most important driver of sales in Pacasmayo's market, the segment is starting to pick up.

Infrastructure has been the driver for more than a year and continues to be so. The company reported on its release that the construction sector is growing at almost 5% YoY in Peru as a whole, driven by infrastructure (mainly PPP projects). In the case of Pacasmayo, we have three important projects: the Motupe riverbanks, the Yanacocha mine, and the Tarata bridge. In previous calls (3Q24, 1Q25), the company had said these projects would provide a tailwind into FY25 and 1H26.

The question is what would happen afterward, and this quarter shed some positive light on that. According to the recent call, agricultural activity is following a positive climatic cycle in Northern Peru (specialty crops like avocados, blueberries, etc.). This industry employs almost 1/3 of all people in the region, meaning better crops move employment and incomes, leading these workers, mostly rural employees, to save more in the form of bags of cement to slowly build and improve their houses.

The impact is clear: Q1 volumes were slightly up, Q2 volumes were up 7%, and Q3 volumes were up 9%. Infrastructure continues to be the main driver, with concrete up 30% for the quarter and the year but only representing 50% of the increase in cement sales (concrete carries 0% to negative LSD gross margins, meaning all profits are profits from cement sales).

Revenues grew 11%, implying there have been some pricing improvements as well, although this has not been addressed in the report or the call.

Margins this year and the next

Plant utilization in the aggregate was up 5 pp versus last year in the same quarter and 4 pp for the year. Overall, a positive driver for gross margins, up 130bps in the quarter.

However, EBITDA margins were down 2 pp for the quarter. The driver was, as mentioned in previous quarters, an increase in Opex of 30%, which, in monetary terms, ate 85% of the improvement of gross profitability for the quarter. The driver has been responsible for the payment or accrual recording of bonuses provided every few years to workers, as the union bargaining agreement is signed.

This points towards much better margins if the union agreement expenses are not recorded next year. If the increase in personnel expenses for the year is fully explained by the union bonus (not clarified), then that is a 2pp lift on EBITDA next year and almost a 10% increase in operating profits.

Looking ahead

The company will probably close the year posting similar growth figures to the rest of the year in the HSD region. At least in 1H26, I think we should not see many changes in this panorama. The question after that is whether there are any new projects announced, of which there has been no mention.

Without projects, concrete, and therefore cement sales could decrease. With lower volumes, utilization falls, and also margins, even if next year will have lower operating expenses, ideally.

So far, it is too soon to tell. I prefer not to bank on HSD growth ahead, but I'm not thinking yet of decreasing revenues, especially if the agricultural economy of the north remains ok.

The company spent some time in the call and the release commenting on the recent ousting of Peru's President by the Congress. The country will elect a new President in March 2026, but so far, it should not affect the business climate, given that, unfortunately, the country is used to political turmoil in the Presidency. In the past two presidential mandates (2016-2021 and 2021-2025), the country has turned over six presidents, as the President is ousted, then the Vice President (this is what happened this year), and then the President of Congress takes office.

Valuation figures remain attractive to fair

Until we have more info on potential projects, I continue to believe the company's growth next year should stabilize around MSD. Whether or not it goes lower or higher will depend on infrastructure, but the tailwind from the first half should still be strong enough, barring problems in the local economy.

In my previous article, I calculated that the company could generate about PEN 245 million in distributable cash at these margins and utilization, based on projections for revenues, margins, and cash utilization on working capital and CAPEX.

Recently, the company announced a dividend for the year of PEN 190 million (PEN 175 million net of treasury shares), or $56 million, a 9.3% yield on the current market cap.

This is not so far from my calculations, and management considered on the call that it is keeping a little more cash and maintaining a dividend level below full capabilities because it wants to continue deleveraging, which I believe is healthy, even if rates are not so high.

Overall though, I believe the company's cash generation capacity remains at about PEN 245 million, or $70 million, which represents an interesting 11.6% yield on the market cap. To this, we need to add the potential for growth between LSD and MSD over the cycle.

In terms of cyclical position, I would believe we are now closer to a local top than to the average, given that both infrastructure and the local economy are doing well. Whether or not this will continue in 2H26 is uncertain.

For the time being, I find the price is still attractive while looking at these developments in terms of growth and margins, with interest for future quarters. I maintain a Buy so far.

data.title: Bank of Hawaii: Asset Repricing Drives Strong Operating Leverage In Q3
data.description:
Shares of Bank of Hawaii (BOH) have been a fairly weak performer over the past year, losing around 8% of their value and trailing the wider regional bank space. Frustratingly, this performance has come despite more upbeat trends at the business level, as balance sheet repricing dynamics continue to drive strong operating leverage and double-digit earnings growth for the bank.

I last covered BOH back in the summer, rating it a Buy. The tailwind coming from fixed-asset repricing was one aspect of my investment case, but more generally, I see BOH as a "Steady Eddy" kind of bank whose loan book can hold up comparatively well in an economic slowdown/downturn. With another set of quarterly results to digest, now is a good time to reassess this investment case. I remain bullish.

Q3 2025 Review: NIM Expansion Drives Strong Operating Leverage

In its third quarter, BOH posted $1.20 in diluted earnings per share, up 23% year-on-year, 7% quarter-on-quarter, and slightly better than the sell-side expected. This result takes the bank's year-to-date EPS to $3.24, up 24% year-on-year.

Net interest income ('NII') accounts for around 75% of BOH's revenue, so trends here are critical to its financial performance. In turn, NII is a function of the level of interest-earning assets and the margin earned on those assets.

BOH generated $136.675 million in NII last quarter, up 16% year-on-year and 5% quarter-on-quarter. This growth is mainly being driven by the ongoing recovery in its net interest margin ('NIM'). The reason for this is that BOH has one of the most rigid balance sheets among the U.S. banks I cover. Not only do fixed-rate residential mortgages account for over 30% of its loan book (around 20% of its earning assets), but it is also holding around $7.5 billion in long-dated investment securities. Since these were largely bought when interest rates were very low, the yield on this part of its balance sheet remains very low.

BOH's NIM clocked in at 2.46% last quarter, up 7 bps quarter-on-quarter and 28 bps year-on-year. Its recent expansion hasn't really been driven by cheaper funding. Indeed, BOH's cost of deposits fell just 1 bp sequentially last quarter to 1.59%. Just to be clear, this is a very strong print. However, because its funding costs are already quite low, it simply doesn't have as much scope to reduce this compared to other banks.

In contrast, BOH has plenty of scope to increase its interest-earning asset yield. This rose 7 bps sequentially last quarter, but it remains quite low at just 4.08%. Looking at the drivers of that, the blended yield of BOH's investment securities expanded by 9 bps quarter-on-quarter to 2.59%. Per the image below, the company disclosed that maturities were running off at a yield of around 2.4%, while new purchases had a blended rate of around 5.3%. Given how low the current yield is, lower interest rates won't really threaten this trend unless they collapse. In other words, repricing in this part of its book is going to be a multi-year tailwind for BOH, supporting its overall earning-asset yield.

There is a similar dynamic at play in the loan book, where front book yields are higher than the back book. This drove BOH's blended loan yield up 6 bps sequentially last quarter to 4.86%.

Now, while lower funding costs have only contributed modestly to BOH's recent NIM expansion, the bank does still have some benefit to come through here. Indeed, management disclosed a 1.54% cost of deposits at the end of last quarter, 5 bps below its period-average rate. Looking ahead, BOH will see some benefit from the ongoing repricing of term deposits. It disclosed a 3.4% average cost here last quarter, while new offerings were being priced at 2.5-3%, according to management. Alongside the aforementioned trends on the asset side, this should continue to power more NIM expansion for BOH.

One feature of this growth is that it drives a lot of operating leverage. BOH doesn't need to go out and hire more employees or open new branches just because its NIM expands, so this incremental NII mostly drops down to pre-tax income. Indeed, BOH's non-interest expenses were $112.387 million last quarter, up just under 5% year-on-year. The fact that this trailed revenue growth by around 1,100 bps is largely what drove its strong EPS growth. This trend should continue alongside NIM expansion, which is why analysts continue to forecast strong earnings growth in the coming years.

Revisiting Its Conservative Credentials

In addition to the tailwind coming from NIM expansion, BOH's relatively low-risk business model was also part of my investment case for the bank. Tariff-related fears from earlier in the year may not have come to pass, but there is still a significant amount of economic uncertainty out there, so it is worth revisiting this part of the thesis.

Positively, BOH's credit quality continues to look very resilient. The bank reported $2.6 million in net charge-offs last quarter, equal to an annualized ratio of just 0.07% of its total loans. Early-stage delinquencies also remain muted. BOH had just $24 million in loans past due 30-59 days at the end of last quarter, down around $6 million from the start of the year.

As you can see below, BOH has a long track record of suffering below-average credit losses. One reason for this is that its loan book is largely secured by real estate. This backs over 85% of its consumer portfolio and around 75% of its commercial book. Across these two categories, its weighted average loan-to-value ratio is just 51%, affording it a large cushion before defaults would turn into actual losses.

The Valuation

Despite BOH's earnings growth and conservative profile, the stock has been a disappointing performer over the past year, with its share price down around 10% in that time. Meanwhile, tangible book value has risen by a similar percentage to $35.56 per share. This contrasting performance has resulted in a clear compression in BOH's P/TBV ratio. As you can see, it is now well below its 10-year average.

One possible explanation for this is the bank's capital position. On the surface, there doesn't appear to be much wrong here, as BOH reported a healthy-looking 11.98% Common Equity Tier 1 ratio last quarter. Not only is that nearly 500 bps above the bank's required minimum, but it is basically in line with its past average level.

Of course, this regulatory ratio excludes the unrealized losses on its investment securities. Measures that do include this, like the tangible common equity ratio, look less strong. BOH's TCE Ratio stood at 5.90% last quarter. That is up significantly from its lows back in 2023, but it's still thinner than I'd like.

This issue will largely correct on its own, as these unrealized losses will fall away as BOH's investment securities get closer to maturity. Still, as a result of this, BOH hasn't been as active in the buyback department as it used to be, as shown below.

The good news is that the recovery in its earnings should open the door for more capital returns. Indeed, given $1.20 in Q3 EPS and a $0.70 per share quarterly dividend, BOH is now back to generating a healthy level of surplus capital. This is only going to improve as its net income continues to grow in the quarters ahead. Given this, management hinted at future buybacks on the earnings call:

But I think given where the stock is at right now, we think that there's a great opportunity to deploy capital into repurchases at this point. We probably are likely to be doing some of that activity here in this quarter and into next year. Obviously, the dividend is important to us, but we think the payout ratio for now is in pretty good shape.

Peter Ho, Chairman & CEO, Bank of Hawaii

That basically sums up why I remain bullish, notwithstanding the stock's poor recent performance. Earnings are growing, the valuation has contracted and, with buybacks back on the table, the shareholder yield should improve as well. Accordingly, I am leaving my Buy rating for BOH in place.

data.title: Roku: A Strategic Pivot May Be About To Unlock Major Upside Value
data.description:
Roku, Inc. (ROKU) announced its third quarter results yesterday after market close, and the response has not been particularly positive, with the stock falling from $100 to $94 in post-market trading as of this writing. I wanted to take a look in at the stock as I actually thought the report was a solid one. Why, then, the decline?

A Solid Earnings Report

Roku’s post-market fall might lead some to think that the earnings report was a disappointment, but I really don’t see it. The earnings report itself was fine. Roku reported another quarter of positive net income and, unlike last quarter, this time its operating income was positive as well. For the first time since 2021 in fact. Despite the Devices segment falling back into negative gross profit territory—it had pushed itself to break even in Q2—Platform profit growth was enough to take operating income to $9.5 million.

Obviously, for a company with a $15 billion market cap that still isn’t very high. But it could be a leading indicator of Roku crossing a tipping point. I believe the drivers of this improved performance are management’s decision to finally pivot to a more subscription-based business model. Since I’ve been arguing for a while that Roku’s advertising focus—which I know many have considered a positive—was actually a detriment to the company, I’m excited by this new turn. And since subscription, unlike advertising, is still in its very early innings, I’m actually impressed by that small $9.5 million number.

My Continuing Skepticism About Advertising

To be clear, I have never argued that Roku cannot generate substantial revenues from free ad-supported streaming television. Roku Channel continues to move up the ladder in Nielsen’s monthly “The Gauge” report of TV timeshare. In fact, Roku is now the leading streaming channel outside of the Big Four—that's YouTube, Amazon.com, Inc.’s (AMZN) Prime Video, Netflix, Inc. (NFLX) and The Walt Disney Company's (DIS) three separate—for now—services.

My concern has always been with how much profit that revenue will yield. I have written about this at length before, so only briefly: Roku’s lack of broad first-party data on its customers means that it cannot target advertisements at specific demos with the precision that Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) or a Google (GOOGL) (GOOG) could. I believe this means that Roku’s ad-supported service could only ever hope to run at break-even no matter how large it got. You can read more about how I analyzed the ad operation to arrive at these conclusions here.

Setting One Thing Straight Before We Dive In

The pushback to my “subs not ads” thesis from bulls has always been that Roku does have a lot of data to use, and certainly that has been management’s position. CEO Anthony Wood insisted yet again on today’s earnings conference call that “we have a lot of data” and also argued that “half of all TV streaming happens on our platform.” The implication is that someone who controls half of TV streaming must have some leverage they can use.

I just want to set the record straight on this one more time; Roku does have 50% household penetration, but it does not have 50% of the TV streaming time. This is because many households have devices from multiple manufacturers in their house; my parents have a Roku, an Amazon Fire TV and an Apple Inc.'s (AAPL) Apple Inc. in various rooms of their home. Wood himself later went back and expressed the number this correctly, “we’re in half the broadband households in the country,” which is accurate. But they do not control half of the streaming time.

A slightly more reliable indicator is the recent survey done by Pixalate, which shows that Roku controls 37% of the open programmatic ads sold on Connected TV devices. That’s a more reasonable estimate that closely aligns with my own research suggesting Roku has about 1/3 of the market. It’s also remarkably steady; a 2017 survey showed Roku with the exact same market share eight years ago.

The Pixalate shows Amazon Fire TV in third at 15%, which is not consistent with my estimates that Amazon controls nearly as large a market share as Roku. However, even Pixalate’s survey is not a complete picture; again, these are “open programmatic” sales, not total sales. Because Roku does not have reliable targeting data from first-party sales and search like Amazon and Google have, it sells more through this channel; Amazon’s market share is correspondingly underrepresented in a poll like this because they do have precise targeting data.

A Long-Awaited Advertising Strategy Shift

That’s probably why after several years of running in the red with their FAST service Roku Channel, Roku has finally decided to bow to the inevitable; the company announced in June that Roku would pool their addressable ad pods inside Amazon’s Demand-Side Platform. I consider this auspicious for Roku as it allows better monetization of their ad-supported viewing. Wood confirmed on the call that Amazon’s DSP integration “just” opened, which to me suggests that it probably wasn’t running until sometime in October. If what we are seeing in these numbers is all pre-Amazon, then the early return to operating income, even narrowly, is all the more impressive.

But if Amazon hasn’t kicked in yet, how did they do it? Management was effusive about the great work of the teams but typically vague about exactly where they’re getting the best results, which for competitive reasons I guess makes sense. But going by their actions, rather than their words, I think it's because they have finally shifted their focus to subscription, ad-free viewing, and by third quarter that transition already was underway.

Finally Embracing Subscriptions

Roku announced when it released its first-quarter earnings six months ago that it had entered into a firm agreement to buy the relatively economical skinny bundle TV service Frndly TV. The bundle offers live programming of a number of secondary channels that are neither sports, news nor broadcast. It is one of the few live services out there with plans below $10 per month.

Some have pointed to Frndly’s “live” status and said that this acquisition furthers Roku’s advertising ambitions. With respect, I don’t see it that way at all. Yes, Frndly offers live streams with ads. But hardly anyone watches that way, because Frndly has nothing that needs to be watched live and even most broadcast networks now see most of their scripted and reality content consumed on an on-demand basis.

Frndly’s real appeal to Roku almost certainly is the tech and features they have developed for subscription-based, ad-free viewing; an area in which Roku has little experience since it has, unwisely in my view, spent the past few years developing ad-supported tech stacks and techniques at the expense of any ad-free offering they might have been able to develop.

Even CBS, a channel with much more “heft” than Roku or Frndly, has confirmed that as much as 85% of the content that its streaming customers consume is on-demand, not live. For a non-sports/news service like Frndly you have to figure that number is a good deal higher still. 90%, at least. Perhaps 95%? 99?!?

And far from bemoaning that fact, Frndly management, who remain with the company post-closing, have positively leaned into it. Frndly offers Look Back, a 72-hour window to rewatch anything that has been broadcast on any of its channels, and a significant portion of its total content budget is allocated to services such as the Dove Channel, which offers all of its content ad-free on demand to subscribers.

Make no mistake, Frndly is an SVOD service, not an AVOD service. In fact, if not in name. And I think that is precisely why Roku wanted it. It is certainly why I wasn’t unhappy to hear they were acquiring it.

Howdy To You, Too

Roku followed up with the launch of Howdy in August. The name notwithstanding, it’s another exciting development as far as I’m concerned. Howdy is a true SVOD service, a la Netflix, Inc. (NFLX) without even Frndly’s largely superfluous live channel offerings.

The reason I consider this a further step is because of Roku’s data. As I said, contrary to management’s protestations, it’s almost certainly not detailed enough to target advertisements effectively. But the one category of data that Roku does have in considerable quantities is viewership data. Roku knows what its customers search for in its Voice Remotes, what they watch on Roku Channel, and, depending on where they find it, sometimes even what they’re watching on other apps.

The best use for this data is targeting content, not targeting advertisements. But with Roku Channel, they couldn’t turn a profit on content, and with Frndly they can’t decide what content they get—Lifetime and others program their own channels, Frndly/Roku merely act as broadcaster and salesman.

With Howdy, Roku will finally pair ad-free subscriptions with their own content curation efforts. While they’re a long way from being the next Netflix, content curation has considerable potential to yield an enduring profit margin for a subscription video service even without top-tier ad-targeting capabilities, because content recommendations can become a self-sustaining internal virtuous cycle in a way that advertising, an intrinsically three-party process, cannot. I wrote before about how the real profit of SVOD, unlike AVOD, lies not in quantity, but in intensity and fungibility of viewership.

Crucial to that is a recommendation engine that becomes embedded in consumers' behavioral expectations. Roku needs to prove to viewers that when they want “something” to watch, as opposed to a specific something, Howdy can find them a suitable piece of content with a minimum amount of wasted browsing time. On the earnings call Roku management also indicated that, while it's still early, they’ve seen good results with their decision to upgrade the recommendations engine to the top row of their eponymous home screen. That too is the right move, and I expect it will continue to bear fruit.

A Very Preliminary Estimate

Precisely because it’s so early, putting numbers on exactly how much profit Roku can generate from this is a little harder. Howdy is a $3 per month service, at least to start, and it won’t be profitable until it achieves critical mass. However, with the Q3 report out we do now see the first full quarter of Frndly TV’s operations.

Despite their press release and earnings call today, Roku has not yet filed their official Q3 10-Q at the time of writing, so I don’t have all the data I would like. For now, I am going to use an imputation model based on the assumption that Howdy will be programmed to produce a similar profit per subscriber to Frndly TV.

In Q2, management disclosed that Frndly represented roughly 1.8 percentage points of the growth in the Platform segment the company had seen, or roughly $15 million. That was for almost exactly two months. At Frndly’s price of $11 per month on their standard, mid-tier plan that comes to roughly 700,000 subscribers.

I continue to believe, as I’ve calculated in prior articles, that Roku’s subscription business is of sufficient size to justify its current market cap. If 700,000 Frndly subscribers can produce $38 million of increased income per year ($9.5 million times four) then at a 25 P/E that is worth almost $1 billion in additional market cap. Currently, Roku and Amazon are performing similarly in the CTV market, and Amazon has roughly 1/3 of Netflix’s viewership in the US. That would suggest Howdy and Frndly together might be able to get to as many as 25 million subscribers in the US. That would be enough to increase market cap by $35 billion, more than tripling Roku’s current share price!

That seems optimistic to me; I suspect these numbers are slanted by the fact that Roku and Amazon both report to the Nielsen Gauge not only their own viewership but also the premium subscriptions—HBO Max, Peacock, etc.—that are routed through their platforms. If we assume they represent half the viewership reported, SVOD will “only” double Roku’s market cap.

Investment Summary

For the past few years, I have been following a straightforward approach to Roku: ride the rollercoaster. That’s not always a good thing in stock trading, but when the highs and lows hold firm it can be very lucrative. I have an entry point around $60 and a sell point around $100. Three times in the past two years, Roku has run right up to the edge of the $100 point, and each time it has done so rebounding off of a sub-$60 floor. It's been possible to simply rinse and repeat.

I am wondering if this pattern is starting to break down. The release of Roku’s second-quarter earnings sent the stock plunging even though they came in mostly better than expected. It went back below $80. But then it rebounded back to $100.

Now it reports another good earnings, the stock falls again anyway….but only to $94. It’s been quite a while since Roku saw the sub-$60 range. And the developments of recent weeks suggest that perhaps it won’t again anytime soon.

I confess to being torn. I’m considerably more positive on Roku now than I was before they pivoted from advertising to subscription. But my high-low formula has been a consistent performer for the past few years. Should I abandon it and buy in now, or await a future dip?

I am honestly unsure. When torn between a weak Buy and a strong Hold, I usually opt for the latter to avoid buying something I lack complete conviction in. But the truth is I don’t lack conviction in Roku’s upside; I just question whether it will be even cheaper later than it is now.

I have not yet bought in, but I may today. I’ll see how it opens, but regardless of whether it returns to its floor again or not, I believe Roku is finally ready to break through its ceiling in the coming months. As such, while I am not completely sure of the timing of my next Roku purchase yet, I am going to give it a Buy rating.

data.title: Lufthansa: FCF Beat, Steady Execution, SOTP Still Compelling -- Buy Reaffirmed
data.description:
Following our update on Deutsche Lufthansa AG's (OTCQX:DLAKF) (OTCQX:DLAKY) Capital Market Day, we provide a further update on the Q3 German flag carrier results. For our new readers, Lufthansa is one of the largest airlines, and its network airlines segment includes SWISS, ITA, Austrian, Brussels Airlines, and a low-cost operator called Eurowings. Additionally, Lufthansa offers aviation services such as Cargo, MRO, and catering.

Lufthansa’s CMD set ambitious margin ambitions, a leaner fleet plan, and clear priorities across business segments. Management expressed confidence in exceeding pre-COVID margin levels, underpinned by a stronger balance sheet, improving FCF, and rising shareholder payouts. At today’s market value, the MRO franchise alone accounts for a large share of the enterprise value.

Q3 Results

In Q3, Lufthansa Group's top-line sales were €11.2 billion, up 11% from the previous year. As the company reported, "this was the strongest quarter in terms of revenue in the history of the Lufthansa Group." EBIT reached €1.3 billion, which was at the previous year's level; however, EBIT margin declined by 60 basis points to 11.9%. Passenger yields were weaker at -5.4% and dragged down by Europe and North America. On a positive note, Lufthansa Cargo continued its positive trajectory with an EBIT of €49 million. Meanwhile, the Lufthansa Technik [MRO] segment reported an EBIT decrease. The division reached an EBIT of €130 million. Going down to the P&L, the company's net profit amounted to €966 million as tax weighed into results.

Source: Lufthansa Q3 results ppt - Fig 1

Why Are We positive?

The company's quarterly results look fine, though the first read skews more negative than positive. However, digging into the report, we remain constructive for the following reason:

MRO Upside Is Still There, And Supportive Cost-Management

The MRO division's core operating profit decreased to €130 million compared to €161 million in Q3 2024. Higher tariffs, a weaker dollar, and additional costs to production ramp-up negatively impacted the segment. That said, top-line sales were up by 10%, and the company reported a solid order book. Looking forward (Fig. 2), Lufthansa won maintenance contracts with EasyJet and Cathay Group.

Within the adjusted EBIT detail, Pax Airlines delivered a flat performance compared to Q3 2024. This result was achieved with ex-fuel unit costs up to 0.5% and should be positively received.

Fig 2

FCF And Deleverage Path

Q3 FCF was materially higher than expected, reaching €818 million (Fig. 1). So, net debt (including pension) fell to €7.2 billion compared to a Q3 2024 of €8.3 billion (Fig. 3). Net pension fell to €2.1 billion, with liquidity higher than €900 million to €11.9 billion. Here at the Lab, we believe this is just the beginning, and this high conviction is reinforced by LHA's turnaround plan to save at least €1.5 billion (Fig. 4).

Fig 3

Pick-up In Airline Search Trends

Cross-checking Google search, new evidence suggests that airline searches have become more popular. The latest trends support Lufthansa very well in Germany and Italy compared to last year, while there is a slight decrease in Spain. This is supportive evidence for the company. Indeed, the company reaffirmed its 2025 full-year forecast.

Fig 4

Valuation

All in, a second pass shows a robust delivery that supports our constructive view. The company confirmed its yearly guidance and reported a higher EBIT than in 2024 (which reached €1.64 billion). Considering this print, Lufthansa's core operating profit amounted to €1.5 billion year-to-date, up by €300 million compared to last year's level. Q4 is a strong quarter for Pax Airlines and Cargo, while it is softer on MRO. Recent booking trends also suggest higher volumes. Our valuation is backed by a sum-of-the-parts thesis, which includes the airlines and MRO segment. On a YTD results, the airlines generated an EBIT of €1.2 billion, and are targeting a 1.6-1.7 billion result by year-end. While the MRO division has an €800 million core operating profit performance. Considering the Cargo business, we believe a €3 billion core operating profit is still achievable.

As reported in our Q3 results paragraph, there was a higher tax rate in the third quarter; however, we applied the corporate tax rate of 25%. So, our income projections are set at €2.1 billion, which derives an EPS of €1.75. With no change to our valuation methodology (6x P/E target), Lufthansa's price is confirmed at €10.5 per share ($12.15 in ADR).

Lufthansa's current market cap is €8.6 billion. As a reminder, a group of private equity firms tried to acquire the MRO division, valuing the subsidiary at approximately $8.7 billion (€7.5 billion). Considering the evolution of FCF, the company will likely exceed its FCF target of €800 million with a potential further debt repayment. We are not underwriting 2026 yet (with supportive evidence from the CMD update). Still, aside from ongoing cost optimization, there is also a higher capacity in 2026, with the company expecting an increase of 4%.

Risks

Our downside risks include the company's ongoing restructuring initiatives, estimated at €1.5 billion, and higher competition from low-cost operators. Lufthansa's risks are also lower due to lower travel demand from business and leisure, changes in oil prices, wage inflation, higher regulatory standards and airport costs, FX changes, and all the negative event risks related to travel, such as airport shutdowns, cybersecurity risks, natural catastrophes, and terrorist actions/attacks.

Conclusion

Q3 results de-risk Lufthansa's investment thesis, and there is upside valuation to consider. Following the CMD release, the company has a clear earnings/transforming roadmap for delivery. Therefore, our buy rating is confirmed.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Portfolio Manager

Mick Rasmussen, CFA

Lead Portfolio Manager

Overview

In the third quarter, U.S. small-cap stocks rallied sharply. The Federal Reserve’s interest rate cut helped lift stocks, as did economic data showing that, while there may be some pockets of concern, the U.S. economy remained steady. In this environment, the Russell 2500 TM Index was up 9.00%. The Wasatch Long/Short Alpha Fund—Investor Class (WALSX) did not keep pace and finished the period down -7.25%.

The quarter was indeed a challenging one for the Fund. In what we would characterize as a very strong “risk-on” environment, the stocks of low-quality companies outperformed the stocks of high-quality businesses. This was a structural headwind for our Fund, which aims to be long on high-quality companies, and to short the stocks of companies we perceive as low quality.

As we explain more in our Outlook section, we believe such positioning will serve us well through the investment cycle. But when low quality outperforms high quality, and when stocks we view as more speculative experience the highest returns, it works against the Fund in two ways. First, our long positions, which again we consider high quality, underperform the benchmark. Second, when we short stocks we perceive as low quality and those stocks rise, our short positions also detract from performance. This dynamic was in play throughout the quarter, in an environment we believe was as speculative and euphoric as the post-Covid market rebound in late 2020 and early 2021.

Given the magnitude of this headwind on Fund performance, we wanted to share a little more detail on the strength of the low-quality rally. As we mentioned last quarter, stocks have rallied sharply since mid-April. And for the most part, the stocks of lower quality companies have been leading the charge.

Many of the top-performing stocks in recent months have been those of companies that have speculative business models, in our view, and often have little to no earnings. They’re often tied to popular investment themes such as artificial intelligence (AI), quantum computing, cryptocurrency, nuclear power, aerospace and defense.

The chart below shows how extreme a headwind this has been. The chart displays one of the ways Wasatch’s research team assesses whether high- or low-quality stocks are in favor. Through a proprietary process, we screen and rank all the companies in the small- and mid-cap universe based on several financial characteristics, such as return on assets and operating profit margins, among other items. Using the aggregate score we obtain, we then compare how the companies in the top quintile perform relative to the bottom quintile. Based on this metric, we’ve rarely seen a low-quality rally approach this magnitude over the past decade.

Additionally, a few statistics point to how low quality has been in favor. The statistics are for the Russell 2000® Growth Index, which is the benchmark for some of our U.S.-focused small cap strategies. For the third quarter, 56 stocks were up 80% or more. Of that group, 82% are unprofitable, and 57% within the group trade at a multiple of 10 times sales or greater. We view this multiple, which looks at revenue and not earnings, as extreme.

We can’t predict when the period favoring the stocks of low-quality companies will end. But periods of low-quality outperformance have historically been short-lived. The stocks of high-quality businesses have outperformed over the long term. We believe that will continue to be the case.

Details of the quarter

Among our long positions, one of the largest detractors was Inspire Medical Systems, Inc. (INSP). Inspire develops implantable neurostimulators for treating obstructive sleep apnea. The company’s shares slid in August after management downgraded full-year 2025 guidance due to delays in the U.S. commercial rollout of its next-generation Inspire V system. The delayed rollout of Inspire V raised questions about execution by management and caused us to trim the position. Additionally, concerns are growing about how GLP-1 drugs may affect Inspire’s addressable market.

Another detractor was Shift4 Payments, Inc. (FOUR). A longtime holding in many of our small-cap funds, Shift4 is a U.S. company that provides payment processing solutions for hospitality, retail and e-commerce businesses. Fundamentals for the company remain solid, as organic revenues grew in the high-teens percentages in the most recent quarter. But the stock has been down in part due to concerns about how a softer macroeconomic environment could affect the company. Additionally, investor sentiment on the company became less favorable after its acquisition of Global Blue, which is a foray into a new customer segment for Shift4. The acquisition also means the company is taking on more debt. Acquisitions can sometimes cause investors angst since they take time to integrate into a company’s normal operations. However, we have confidence in Shift4’s leadership and their ability to execute on Global Blue.

Freshpet, Inc. (FRPT) also detracted. The company manufactures refrigerated dog and cat food and treats. In general, pet owners have been less willing to pay for premium fresh pet food in the current economic environment. However, we continue to like the company. Even in today’s environment, we’ve seen Freshpet take market share from other premium pet foods. And we believe investments the company has made to expand its manufacturing footprint have reached a tipping point that could drive cashflows meaningfully higher.

Medpace Holdings (MEDP) was the top contributor to Fund performance during the quarter. The contract research organization provides drug development, clinical trial management, and regulatory services to biotech, pharmaceutical, and medical device companies. Medpace’s shares jumped after management reported strong revenue and earnings growth and raised its full-year guidance. We believe those results are particularly impressive in light of the fact there’s been a slowdown in the biotech funding cycle.

Another top contributor was Fabrinet (FN). The company designs, manufactures, and tests complex optoelectronic and photonic components, modules, and precision optical assemblies for customers in a variety of industries. Some of its products are used in data centers, which makes the company tied somewhat to AI. As mentioned, this has been a popular theme among investors, and likely helped drive the stock higher. However, we don’t hold the stock as a thematic play on AI. The company is experiencing strong adoption of its products with both new and existing customers. We believe Fabrinet is well positioned to grow regardless of AI.

Turning to short positions, detractors from Fund performance were those stocks that rose in price. One of the largest detractors was Opendoor Technologies, Inc. (OPEN). The company operates a digital real estate platform that provides services for buying and selling residential properties online. We viewed the company as lower quality, given questions about the viability of the business model, and shorted the stock to offset some of our long positions tied to the housing industry. However, Opendoor became a “meme stock” popular among investors in Reddit investment forums and the stock price rose as investors piled in. We did not want to invest against that type of market dynamic and quickly covered the short position.

Among shorts, contributors to Fund performance were those stocks that declined in price. One of the largest contributors was Sweetgreen, Inc. (SG), a fast-casual restaurant chain that specializes in made-to-order salads and grain bowls. We short the position as a hedge against some of our long positions in the consumer-discretionary and consumer-staples sectors. Companies in these sectors can be impacted when consumer spending turns weak. And this quarter, most stocks of restaurant companies were indeed down due to such concerns. (Current and future holdings are subject to risk and change.)

Outlook and Positioning

While performance this period was painful, we wouldn’t expect the Fund to keep up in what we view as an extreme risk-on environment. We’re seeing a lot of capital flow to companies with highly speculative business models, where there may not even be a commercially viable product or service yet—just a research department and a business plan. In our view, the amount of speculation in the market today is eerily similar to that of the internet bubble, or the post-Covid environment in late 2020 and 2021.

However, the speculation that has taken place leaves us excited about the Fund’s return potential from here. The run up in stock prices of what we believe are low-quality businesses has given us an opportunity to short stocks that look extremely overpriced. And on the long side, our companies have generally continued to generate strong earnings growth, though we believe fundamentals have mattered less to investors in a speculative market.

Given the way we feel about the portfolio and the market environment, we’ve increased the Fund’s gross exposure, and have done so by increasing both long and short exposure. We can’t predict when the current speculative, risk-on environment will subside. But when it does, we believe the Fund is well positioned for it.

Thank you for the opportunity to manage your assets.

Sincerely,

Mick Rasmussen
